perturbation.original_text: If you do not make the extra payment within 60 days from the date we notify you of your share of the deficiency, the amount will be charged as an indebtedness against the contract with interest compounded at the rate of 5% per year.
perturbation.changed_text: If you do not make the extra payment within 10 days from the date we notify you of your share of the deficiency, the amount will be charged as an indebtedness against the contract with interest compounded at the rate of 5% per year.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the payment period to 10 days could be considered an unreasonable timeframe, especially given the context of financial hardship that leads to solvency issues. This could contradict regulations requiring fair and reasonable practices by financial institutions.
perturbation.law_explanation: This modification reduces the payment period to 10 days. This could be considered an unreasonable timeframe, and Regulation X 12 CFR § 1024.41 requires mortgage servicers to provide borrowers with a reasonable amount of time to respond to communications regarding potential loss mitigation options.

perturbation.original_text: You may transfer ownership of this contract in accordance with our bylaws.
perturbation.changed_text: You may transfer ownership of this contract only with our express written consent, which may be withheld for any reason.
perturbation.explanation: Adding the condition that ownership transfer requires express written consent, which can be withheld for any reason, unduly restricts the policyholder's rights. This could violate state laws that protect the rights of contract holders, particularly regarding the transfer of ownership and assignment of benefits.
perturbation.law_explanation: This change, requiring express written consent for contract transfer, which can be withheld for any reason, restricts the policyholder's rights. This conflicts with UCC § 9-406(d) which generally invalidates contractual terms that restrict the assignment of accounts or payment intangibles, preventing parties from unduly restricting the transfer of contractual rights.

perturbation.original_text: Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus. This contract's share, if any, will be credited as a dividend. Since we do not expect this contract to contribute to divisible surplus, it is not expected that any dividends will be credited.
perturbation.changed_text: We retain the sole discretion to determine our divisible surplus, and dividends, if any, will be credited to you at our discretion. The determination of divisible surplus and the allocation of dividends are not subject to judicial review.
perturbation.explanation: Stating that the determination of divisible surplus and allocation of dividends are not subject to judicial review attempts to shield the company's decisions from legal scrutiny, which is generally not permissible under the law.
perturbation.law_explanation: The modification attempts to shield the company's dividend decisions from judicial review, this conflicts with basic principles of contract law and fiduciary duty and with Wisconsin Statute § 611.31(2) (as Thrivent is based in Appleton, WI), which governs the distribution of dividends by insurance companies and implies a standard of fairness and reasonableness that is subject to legal oversight, even if not explicitly stated.
